children.definition: SOFR/reference rate floor included in yield comparison if higher than the actual reference rate. Creates additional yield when market rates are below the floor. DLS Preferred Row 11 alternative specifies: 'any interest rate floors.' 'To the extent the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans is greater than such all-in yield with respect to any Existing Term Loans solely as a result of a higher interest rate floor, then the interest rate margin increase shall be effectuated solely by increasing the interest rate floor on any applicable Existing Term Loans.' Distinguished from cash interest by only creating value in low-rate environments.
children.name: SOFR Floor

children.definition: What components are included in the all-in yield comparison for MFN purposes. Learning Material: 'In addition to interest, lenders may be compensated by receiving an upfront fee or by funding a loan at a discount to par (OID). Such fee or yield should be taken into account.' DLS Preferred Row 11 alternative: 'All-in Yield including interest rate margins, any interest rate floors, original issue discount and upfront fees (based on the lesser of a four-year average life to maturity or the remaining life to maturity), but excluding reasonable and customary arrangement, structuring and underwriting fees.' If MFN applies only to interest margin and not yield, it must be flagged.
children.name: Yield Definition Components

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: “All-in Yield” all-in yield (including interest rate margins, any interest rate floors, original issue discount and upfront fees (based on the lesser of a four-year average life to maturity or the remaining life to maturity), but excluding reasonable and customary arrangement, structuring and underwriting fees) applicable to any Incremental Term Loans will not be more than 0.50% higher than the corresponding all-in yield (determined on the same basis) applicable to the Term Loans and any existing Incremental Term Loans (each an “Existing Term Loan”), unless the interest rate margin with respect to each applicable Existing Term Loan is increased by an amount equal to the difference between the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans and the all-in yield on such Existing Term Loans as applicable, minus, 0.50%; it being agreed that to the extent the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans is greater than such all-in yield with respect to any Existing Term Loans solely as a result of a higher interest rate floor, then the interest rate margin increase shall be effectuated solely by increasing the interest rate floor on any applicable Existing Term Loans. [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: MFN protection for life (lender) vs no MFN (borrower). Market typically has sunset (12-24 months). | ROFR required (lender) vs no ROFR. Market mixed — PC typically requires, BSL typically does not. | Strict maturity floors (lender) vs inside-maturity thresholds (borrower). Market allows limited inside-maturity amounts. | Pro rata sharing (lender) vs flexible waterfall (borrower). Market standard: mandatory prepayments pro rata; voluntary may be flexible.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: All-in yield includes rate margins, floors, OID and upfront fees (4-year average life); excludes arrangement/structuring fees

children.definition: Whether MFN applies to all-in yield (including OID/upfront fees) or just interest rate margin. DLS Preferred Row 11 alternative specifies all-in yield. PC Term Comparison: 'Use conservative definition of All In Yield.' If MFN applies only to interest margin and not yield, borrowers can circumvent it through higher OID or upfront fees.
children.name: Yield vs. Rate Application

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: “All-in Yield” all-in yield (including interest rate margins, any interest rate floors, original issue discount and upfront fees (based on the lesser of a four-year average life to maturity or the remaining life to maturity), but excluding reasonable and customary arrangement, structuring and underwriting fees) applicable to any Incremental Term Loans will not be more than 0.50% higher than the corresponding all-in yield (determined on the same basis) applicable to the Term Loans and any existing Incremental Term Loans (each an “Existing Term Loan”), unless the interest rate margin with respect to each applicable Existing Term Loan is increased by an amount equal to the difference between the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans and the all-in yield on such Existing Term Loans as applicable, minus, 0.50%; it being agreed that to the extent the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans is greater than such all-in yield with respect to any Existing Term Loans solely as a result of a higher interest rate floor, then the interest rate margin increase shall be effectuated solely by increasing the interest rate floor on any applicable Existing Term Loans. [...]

Market mixed — PC typically requires, BSL typically does not. | Strict maturity floors (lender) vs inside-maturity thresholds (borrower). Market allows limited inside-maturity amounts. | Pro rata sharing (lender) vs flexible waterfall (borrower). Market standard: mandatory prepayments pro rata; voluntary may be flexible.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: MFN based on all-in yield, not just rate margin; captures floor differentials and OID that pure margin comparison misses

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 11 alternative; PC Term Comparison line 246

children.definition: Basis point cushion before the MFN adjustment activates. If the incremental facility yield exceeds existing loan yield by more than this threshold, existing loans are repriced upward. DLS Preferred: '50 bps of MFN for life.' Learning Material: 'An incremental term loan is permitted to have 50-10 basis points of additional yield compared to the closing date term loans. Typically banks have flex to reduce any cushion greater than 5 basis points.' PC Term Comparison: '50 bps standard even for Aggressive UMM/BSLR.' Distinguished from the MFN scope (which determines what debt triggers the test) by governing the sensitivity threshold for activation.
children.name: Trigger Threshold

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 236

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 11 alternative (yield definition implies floating rate scope)

children.definition: Whether required lenders can waive MFN protection. Observed in BSL deals. Learning Material notes that required lenders have broad amendment authority. DLS Preferred: MFN is a highlighted negotiation item but not listed as a sacred right requiring all-lender consent. Distinguished from other exceptions by being a discretionary waiver rather than a structural carveout.
children.name: Required Lender Waiver
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 93 (voting)

children.definition: Carveouts allowing incremental debt to exceed the MFN pricing threshold without triggering repricing. DLS Preferred Row 11 alternative lists MFN exceptions: '(i) 12/24 months sunset on MFN, (ii) dollar threshold of debt not subject to MFN, (iii) MFN incurred under free and clear basket/unlimited basket not subject to MFN, (iv) debt that matures more than 12/24 months outside the maturity date of the Term Facility not subject to MFN and (v) 75 bps of MFN.' PC Term Comparison lists additional exceptions including capped amount, currency, and acquisition carveouts.
children.name: MFN Exceptions

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: “All-in Yield” all-in yield (including interest rate margins, any interest rate floors, original issue discount and upfront fees (based on the lesser of a four-year average life to maturity or the remaining life to maturity), but excluding reasonable and customary arrangement, structuring and underwriting fees) applicable to any Incremental Term Loans will not be more than 0.50% higher than the corresponding all-in yield (determined on the same basis) applicable to the Term Loans and any existing Incremental Term Loans (each an “Existing Term Loan”), unless the interest rate margin with respect to each applicable Existing Term Loan is increased by an amount equal to the difference between the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans and the all-in yield on such Existing Term Loans as applicable, minus, 0.50%; it being agreed that to the extent the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans is greater than such all-in yield with respect to any Existing Term Loans solely as a result of a higher interest rate floor, then the interest rate margin increase shall be effectuated solely by increasing the interest rate floor on any applicable Existing Term Loans. [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: MFN protection for life (lender) vs no MFN (borrower). Market typically has sunset (12-24 months). | ROFR required (lender) vs no ROFR. Market mixed — PC typically requires, BSL typically does not. | Strict maturity floors (lender) vs inside-maturity thresholds (borrower). Market allows limited inside-maturity amounts. | Pro rata sharing (lender) vs flexible waterfall (borrower). Market standard: mandatory prepayments pro rata; voluntary may be flexible.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No MFN exceptions; reject sunset, dollar threshold, free-and-clear carveout, and outside-maturity exemptions

children.definition: MFN protection expiration triggered by the borrower achieving a specified leverage ratio target, rather than a fixed calendar date. Performance-based sunset ties MFN duration to credit improvement — once the borrower deleverages to the target level, the MFN is no longer needed because the credit has improved sufficiently that new lenders should be willing to lend at existing pricing. This is borrower-favorable compared to no sunset (per PC Term Comparison line 230: no sunset is the standard outside Aggressive UMM/BSL) but more lender-protective than a fixed-date sunset because it requires actual performance improvement rather than mere passage of time.
children.name: Performance-Based Sunset

children.definition: MFN protection variant where the yield-differential threshold progressively decreases over time before the MFN expires entirely. For example, the MFN threshold might start at 50bps (standard per PC Term Comparison line 231), step down to 25bps after 12 months, and expire entirely at 18 months. This graduated approach gives existing lenders decreasing protection over time, reflecting the principle that the risk of adverse repricing diminishes as the credit seasons and existing lenders have more opportunities to exit or renegotiate. Per PCTC line 229, the standard sunset period for Aggressive UMM/BSL is '12-18 months,' within which graduated step-downs typically operate.
children.name: Graduated Sunset

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: “All-in Yield” all-in yield (including interest rate margins, any interest rate floors, original issue discount and upfront fees (based on the lesser of a four-year average life to maturity or the remaining life to maturity), but excluding reasonable and customary arrangement, structuring and underwriting fees) applicable to any Incremental Term Loans will not be more than 0.50% higher than the corresponding all-in yield (determined on the same basis) applicable to the Term Loans and any existing Incremental Term Loans (each an “Existing Term Loan”), unless the interest rate margin with respect to each applicable Existing Term Loan is increased by an amount equal to the difference between the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans and the all-in yield on such Existing Term Loans as applicable, minus, 0.50%; it being agreed that to the extent the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans is greater than such all-in yield with respect to any Existing Term Loans solely as a result of a higher interest rate floor, then the interest rate margin increase shall be effectuated solely by increasing the interest rate floor on any applicable Existing Term Loans. [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: MFN protection for life (lender) vs no MFN (borrower). Market typically has sunset (12-24 months). | ROFR required (lender) vs no ROFR. Market mixed — PC typically requires, BSL typically does not. | Strict maturity floors (lender) vs inside-maturity thresholds (borrower). Market allows limited inside-maturity amounts. | Pro rata sharing (lender) vs flexible waterfall (borrower). Market standard: mandatory prepayments pro rata; voluntary may be flexible.

must have a ROFR on all Incremental Facilities

Collateral: Can only be secured by Collateral and must be pari passu with the Term Facility [...]

children.definition: Period after which MFN protection expires, removing the repricing risk for the borrower. DLS Preferred: MFN for life (no sunset). PC Term Comparison: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: 12-18 months. Otherwise no sunset.' DLS alternative lists MFN exceptions including 'MFN incurred under free and clear basket/unlimited basket not subject to MFN' and '12/24 months sunset on MFN.' Learning Material: 'MFN provision falls away after a specified period after closing. Your client may want flex to keep the MFN provision indefinitely or at least 2 years.'

children.name: Variable / Shadow MFN
children.definition: MFN protection variant where the yield-differential threshold is not fixed at a single basis-point level but varies based on deal characteristics such as the weighted average life to maturity (WALM) of the incremental tranche, the credit rating, or the market spread environment at the time of incurrence. A variable shadow MFN might provide: 50bps for pari passu term loans (standard per PCTC line 231), 75bps for junior lien debt, and 100bps for unsecured IED — reflecting the different pricing premiums inherent in each debt type. Per PC Term Comparison line 246: 'Use conservative definition of All In Yield,' highlighting that the yield calculation methodology (not just the threshold) is critical for effective MFN protection.
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 231, 246 (50bps standard, conservative All In Yield)

definition: Most Favored Nation pricing protection ensuring existing lenders are not economically disadvantaged when incremental debt is incurred at a higher yield. Learning Material: 'General concept is that the borrower will not pay a higher yield on incremental loans than the yield paid on the closing date loans. If incremental loans would have a higher yield, the yield on the closing date loans is required to be increased.' DLS Preferred Row 11: '50 bps of MFN for life.' PC Term Comparison: '50 bps standard even for Aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions.' Scope, sunset, carveouts, and threshold amount are the key negotiation variables.

market_benchmarks.scope_conservative: All pari debt including IED, ratio debt, acquisition debt
market_benchmarks._source: DLS Preferred Row 11; PC Term Comparison lines 228-240; Incremental components.json mfn_protection
